Message.Title: Needham & Company Gives Buy Rating to Yahoo! Price Target $19
Message.Msg: Yahoo!‘s stock had its “buy” rating reaffirmed by research analysts at Needham & Company in a report released on Tuesday. They currently have a $19.00 target price on the stock. A number of other analysts have also recently weighed in on YHOO. Analysts at Credit Suisse initiated coverage on shares of Yahoo! in a research note to investors on Wednesday, October 10th. They set a “neutral” rating on the stock. Separately, analysts at Piper Jaffray reiterated a “neutral” rating on shares of Yahoo! in a research note to investors on Wednesday, October 3rd. They now have an $18.00 price target on the stock. Finally, analysts at Goldman Sachs initiated coverage on shares of Yahoo! in a research note to investors on Thursday, September 27th. They set a “buy” rating on the stock with a price target of $22.

Topic.Title: Apple should acquire Yahoo as a whole for search...

Message.Msg: "At current price, Apple is paying $0 to get the whole of Yahoo and its search patents and market share. I can't think of a reason of why not." Oh, I can think of about 50 reasons why Apple would not buy Yahoo. But lets just go with 2 reasons. 1) Apple is developing the killer search app in Siri and it even has Goog running a bit scared. So Apple doesn't need Yahoo. (Assuming there is any search function left in Yahoo decaying husk.) 2) No matter how cheap Yahoo is, you don't buy a company running through the end of its product lifecyle while dramatic marketplace changes are beginning to occur which will make Gambino family members look healthy in the morgue.

Topic.Title: Apple should acquire Yahoo as a whole for search...

Message.Msg: Hotmodel: Romney's already promised Big Bird the job so it's staying in the USA. Square would be an interesting acquisition. If I am understanding a number of these new transaction entrants correctly the big losers are going to be Visa and Mastercard and those high transaction fees they charge. The lower the transaction fees the more merchants are willing to accept credit for $1 items, so then more opportunity to coupon and sell ads. Unfortunately, I have a feeling that Marissa is instead going to make a run at Open Table. It is just a feeling I have and not based on anything other than her Goog acquisition of Zagat. But, open table could be transformed into a service for a lot of other customer service type companies.

California will be in play by the end of next week. Here is why I say Romney will win. Polling data from metropolitan areas with high Gay populations are leaning toward Romney at between 35% and 40% up from the usual 8% to 10%. The general belief is that in metro areas Gays don't worry about their lifestyle being infringed upon, but since so many of them are self employed or business owners they are far more concerned about taxes and regulations and such this time around. That is enough of a swing to let out state votes carry Romney to victory in places like Colorado, Wisconsin, and yes California.

Message.Title: SQNM is going to be my retirement
Message.Msg: Let's say you took all of your money and bought SQNM after hours in chunks every day. When would you retire? Let's also assume you are supposed to be retired, but you thought: I am not making enough in yield to live well, so I will take on some risk with all of my money.

Topic.Title: When will YHOO get credit for beating earnings 5 Q's in a row, being a tech co. that....

Message.Msg: Beating earnings estimates only tells us that they are not doing quite as badly as the analysts think. Not that they are doing well. Getting 25 cents when the estimates predicted 22 and a well run constantly growing company would be showing 60 to 80 is not good.

Topic.Title: Revolving door of CEO's, COO's, CIO's, CFO's, VP's... and they all got PAIDj and continue to get PAID. When's the last time you as a shareholder got PAID?

Message.Msg: It's like rearranging deck chairs on the Titanic.

Message.Title: Yahoo! site improvements
Message.Msg: Anyone else noticing enhancements small and large to Yahoo! sites? For example, the desktop homepage looks to be enhanced just a little. Sometimes when I go to the mobile homepage on iPhone I think i'm getting a beta test of a new site but then other times it goes back to the original. This also happend with Yahoo! images. I must say, every new enhancement, small or large, seems to be for the better. Mayer has described a few times how Google 'birdwalked' their way to perfection. I believe we're seeing it here with Yahoo!
